section.title: Bases as Coordinate Systems

ol.li: Learn to view a basis as a coordinate system on a subspace.
Recipes: compute the \cB-coordinates of a vector, compute the usual coordinates of a vector from its \cB-coordinates.
Picture: the \cB-coordinates of a vector using its location on a nonstandard coordinate grid.

section.p: In this section, we interpret a basis of a subspace V as a coordinate system on V, and we learn how to write a vector in V in that coordinate system.

statement.p: If \cB = \{v_1,v_2,\ldots,v_m\} is a basis for a subspace V, then any vector x in V can be written as a linear combination x = c_1v_1 + c_2v_2 + \cdots + c_mv_m in exactly one way.

proof.p:
Recall that to say \cB is a basis for V means that \cB spans V and \cB is linearly independent. Since \cB spans V, we can write any x in V as a linear combination of v_1,v_2,\ldots,v_m. For uniqueness, suppose that we had two such expressions:
x &= c_1v_1 + c_2v_2 + \cdots + c_mv_m x &= c_1'v_1 + c_2'v_2 + \cdots + c_m'v_m.
Subtracting the first equation from the second yields 0 = x-x = (c_1-c_1')v_1 + (c_2-c_2')v_2 + \cdots + (c_m-c_m')v_m. Since \cB is linearly independent, the only solution to the above equation is the trivial solution: all the coefficients must be zero. It follows that c_i-c_i' for all i, which proves that c_1=c_1',\,c_2=c_2',\ldots,\,c_m=c_m'.

section.p: What exactly are coordinates, anyway? One way to think of coordinates is that they give directions for how to get to a certain point from the origin. In the above example, the linear combination 3e_1+5e_2-2e_3 can be thought of as the following list of instructions: start at the origin, travel 3 units north, then travel 5 units east, then 2 units down.

statement.p: Let \cB=\{v_1,v_2,\ldots,v_m\} be a basis of a subspace V, and let x = c_1v_1 + c_2v_2 + \cdots + c_mv_m be a vector in V. The coefficients c_1,c_2,\ldots,c_m are the coordinates of x with respect to \cB. The \cB-coordinate vector of x is the vector [x]_\cB = \vec{c_1 c_2 \vdots, c_m} \quad\text{in }\R^m.

section.p: \cB-coordinatesinformally If we change the basis, then we can still give instructions for how to get to the point (3,5,-2), but the instructions will be different. Say for example we take the basis v_1=e_1+e_2 = \vec{1,1,0}, \quad v_2=e_2 = \vec{0 1 0},\quad v_3 =e_3 = \vec{0 0 1}. We can write (3,5,-2) in this basis as 3v_1+2v_2-2v_3. In other words: start at the origin, travel northeast 3 times as far as v_1, then 2 units east, then 2 units down. In this situation, we can say that 3 is the v_1-coordinate of (3,5,-2), 2 is the v_2-coordinate of (3,5,-2), and -2 is the v_3-coordinate of (3,5,-2).

bluebox.p: The above gives a way of using \R^m to label the points of a subspace of dimension m: a point is simply labeled by its \cB-coordinate vector. For instance, if we choose a basis for a plane, we can label the points of that plane with the points of \R^2.

statement.p:
Define v_1 = \vec{1 1},\; v_2 = \vec{1 -1},\quad \cB = \{v_1,\,v_2\}.
Verify that \cB is a basis for \R^2.
If [w]_\cB = {1\choose 2}, then what is w?
Find the \cB-coordinates of v = {5\choose 3}.

example.title: A coordinate system on a plane

statement.p:
Define v_1 = \vec{1 0 1},\; v_2 = \vec{1 1 1},\quad \cB = \{v_1,\,v_2\}, \quad V = \Span\{v_1,\,v_2\}.
Verify that \cB is a basis for V.
If [w]_\cB = {5\choose 2}, then what is w?
Find the \cB-coordinates of v = \vec{5 3 5}.

ol.li: We need to verify that \cB spans V, and that it is linearly independent. By definition, V is the span of \cB; since v_1 and v_2 are not multiples of each other, they are linearly independent. This shows in particular that V is a plane.
To say [w]_\cB={5\choose 2} means that 5 is the v_1-coordinate of w, and that 2 is the v_2-coordinate: w = 5v_1 + 2v_2 = 5\vec{1 0 1} + 2\vec{1 1 1} = \vec{7 2 7}.

We have to solve the vector equation v=c_1v_1 + c_2v_2 in the unknowns c_1,c_2. We form an augmented matrix and row reduce: \amat{1 1 5; 0 1 3; 1 1 5} \quad\xrightarrow{\text{RREF}}\quad \amat{1 0 2; 0 1 3; 0 0 0}. We have c_1=2 and c_2=3, so v = 2v_1+3v_2 and [v]_\cB = {2\choose 3}.

figure.caption: A picture of the plane V and the basis \cB = \{v_1,v_2\}. The violet grid is a picture of the coordinate system defined by the basis \cB; one set of lines measures the v_1-coordinate, and the other set measures the v_2-coordinate. Use the sliders to find the \cB-coordinates of v.

example.title: A coordinate system on another plane

statement.p:
Define v_1 = \vec{2 3 2},\; v_2 = \vec[r]{-1 1 1},\; v_3 = \vec{2 8 6},\quad V = \Span\{v_1,\,v_2,\,v_3\}.
Find a basis \cB for V.
Find the \cB-coordinates of x = \vec{4 11 8}.

ol.li:
We write V as the column space of a matrix A, then row reduce to find the pivot columns, as in this . A = \mat{2 -1 2; 3 1 8; 2 1 6} \quad\xrightarrow{\text{RREF}}\quad \mat{1 0 2; 0 1 2; 0 0 0}.
The first two columns are pivot columns, so we can take \cB=\{v_1,v_2\} as our basis for V.

We have to solve the vector equation x = c_1v_1 + c_2v_2. We form an augmented matrix and row reduce: \amat{2 -1 4; 3 1 11; 2 1 8} \quad\xrightarrow{\text{RREF}}\quad \amat{1 0 3; 0 1 2; 0 0 0}. We have c_1 = 3 and c_2 = 2, so x=3v_1 + 2v_2, and thus [x]_\cB = {3\choose 2}.

figure.caption: A picture of the plane V and the basis \cB = \{v_1,v_2\}. The violet grid is a picture of the coordinate system defined by the basis \cB; one set of lines measures the v_1-coordinate, and the other set measures the v_2-coordinate. Use the sliders to find the \cB-coordinates of x.

bluebox.title: Recipes: \cB-coordinates
bluebox.p:
If \cB = \{v_1,v_2,\ldots,v_m\} is a basis for a subspace V and x is in V, then [x]_\cB = \vec{c_1 c_2 \vdots, c_m} \sptxt{means} x = c_1v_1 + c_2v_2 + \cdots + c_mv_m.
Finding the \cB-coordinates of x means solving the vector equation x = c_1v_1 + c_2v_2 + \cdots + c_mv_m in the unknowns c_1,c_2,\ldots,c_m. This generally means row reducing the augmented matrix \amat[c]{| | ,, | |; v_1 v_2 \cdots, v_m x; | | ,, | |}.

remark.p: Let \cB = \{v_1,v_2,\ldots,v_m\} be a basis of a subspace V. Finding the \cB-coordinates of a vector x means solving the vector equation x = c_1v_1 + c_2v_2 + \cdots + c_mv_m. If x is not in V, then this equation has no solution, as x is not in V = \Span\{v_1,v_2,\ldots,v_m\}. In other words, the above equation is inconsistent when x is not in V.
